Generation I.Red: Burrows deep underground in arid locations far from water. It only emerges to hunt for food.
Generation I.Green: (This entry was originally untranslated in English until it was reused in Pokémon FireRed .)
Generation I.Blue: Burrows deep underground in arid locations far from water. It only emerges to hunt for food.
Generation I.Yellow: Its body is dry. When it gets cold at night, its hide is said to become coated with a fine dew.
Generation I.Stadium: When hunting, it hides at the lip of its burrow. If prey comes close, it lunges out and drags in the prey instantly.

Generation II.Gold: If it fell from a great height, this Pok é mon could save itself by rolling into a ball and bouncing.
Generation II.Silver: Disliking water, it lives in deep burrows in arid areas. It can roll itself instantly into a ball.
Generation II.Crystal: It prefers dry, sandy places because it uses the sand to protect itself when threatened.
Generation II.Stadium 2: If it fell from a great height, this Pok é mon could save itself by rolling into a ball and bouncing. (Pokémon Red, Silver, or Crystal inserted) Disliking water, it lives in deep burrows in arid areas. It can roll itself instantly into a ball. (Pokémon Blue, Gold, or Yellow inserted)

Generation III.Ruby: Sandshrew 's body is configured to absorb water without waste, enabling it to survive in an arid desert. This Pok é mon curls up to protect itself from its enemies.
Generation III.Sapphire: Sandshrew has a very dry hide that is extremely tough. The Pok é mon can roll into a ball that repels any attack. At night, it burrows into the desert sand to sleep.
Generation III.Emerald: When it curls up in a ball, it can make any attack bounce off harmlessly. Its hide has turned tough and solid as a result of living in the desert.
Generation III.FireRed: It burrows and lives underground. If threatened, it curls itself up into a ball for protection.
Generation III.LeafGreen: Burrows deep underground in arid locations far from water. It only emerges to hunt for prey.

Generation IV.Diamond: To protect itself from attackers, it curls up into a ball. It lives in arid regions with minimal rainfall.
Generation IV.Pearl: To protect itself from attackers, it curls up into a ball. It lives in arid regions with minimal rainfall.
Generation IV.Platinum: To protect itself from attackers, it curls up into a ball. It lives in arid regions with minimal rainfall.
Generation IV.HeartGold: If it fell from a great height, this Pokémon could save itself by rolling into a ball and bouncing.
Generation IV.SoulSilver: Disliking water, it lives in deep burrows in arid areas. It can roll itself instantly into a ball.

Generation V.Black: To protect itself from attackers, it curls up into a ball. It lives in arid regions with minimal rainfall.
Generation V.White: To protect itself from attackers, it curls up into a ball. It lives in arid regions with minimal rainfall.
Generation V.Black 2: It digs deep burrows to live in. When in danger, it rolls up its body to withstand attacks.
Generation V.White 2: It digs deep burrows to live in. When in danger, it rolls up its body to withstand attacks.

Generation VI.X: It burrows and lives underground. If threatened, it curls itself up into a ball for protection.
Generation VI.Y: Disliking water, it lives in deep burrows in arid areas. It can roll itself instantly into a ball.
Generation VI.Omega Ruby: Sandshrew's body is configured to absorb water without waste, enabling it to survive in an arid desert. This Pokémon curls up to protect itself from its enemies.
Generation VI.Alpha Sapphire: Sandshrew has a very dry hide that is extremely tough. The Pokémon can roll into a ball that repels any attack. At night, it burrows into the desert sand to sleep.

Generation VII.Sun: It lives on snowy mountains. Its steel shell is very hard—so much so, it can't roll its body up into a ball.
Generation VII.Moon: An ancient tradition of Alolan festivals, still carried on to this day, is a competition to slide Sandshrew across ice as far as one can.
Generation VII.Ultra Sun: After fleeing a volcanic eruption, it ended up moving to an area of snowy mountains. Its ice shell is as hard as steel.
Generation VII.Ultra Moon: The skin on its back is as hard as steel. Predators go after its soft belly, so it clings to the ground desperately.
Generation VII.Let's Go Pikachu: Its ice-covered body lets it slide across the ground with bullet-like speed, sending its enemies flying when it hits them.
Generation VII.Let's Go Eevee: Its ice-covered body lets it slide across the ground with bullet-like speed, sending its enemies flying when it hits them.

Generation VIII.Sword: Life on mountains covered with deep snow has granted this Pokémon a body of ice that's as hard as steel.
Generation VIII.Shield: It lives in snowy mountains on southern islands. When a blizzard rolls in, this Pokémon hunkers down in the snow to avoid getting blown away.
Generation VIII.Brilliant Diamond: To protect itself from attackers, it curls up into a ball. It lives in arid regions with minimal rainfall.
Generation VIII.Shining Pearl: To protect itself from attackers, it curls up into a ball. It lives in arid regions with minimal rainfall.

Generation IX.Scarlet: It lives on snowy mountains. Its steel shell is very hard—so much so, it can’t roll its body up into a ball.
Generation IX.Violet: An ancient tradition of Alolan festivals, still carried on to this day, is a competition to slide Sandshrew across ice as far as one can.
